title: Ticket #3548: chirp write appears to be broken
description:
$ cat filetowrite

abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz123456789A

$ cat /tmp/tmpfiletowrite

000000000000000000000000000000000

/usr/libexec/condor/condor_chirp write -offset 0 -stride 0 0 /tmp/tmpfiletowrite filetowrite

$cat /tmp/tmpfiletowrite

abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz123456789A

/usr/libexec/condor/condor_chirp write -offset 2 -stride 0 0 /tmp/tmpfiletowrite filetowrite $cat /tmp/tmpfiletowrite 00abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz123456789A

/usr/libexec/condor/condor_chirp write -offset 2 -stride 3 4 /tmp/tmpfiletowrite filetowrite

$cat /tmp/tmpfiletowrite

00abc0def0ghi0jkl0mno0pqr0stu0vwx yz123456789A

which is actually a file with <nul> characters due to the original length of /tmp/tmpfiletowrite

00abc0def0ghi0jkl0mno0pqr0stu0vwx yz1<nul>234<nul>567<nul>89A<nul>

The <nul> characters aren't the problem. In the above examples there is nothing to control the length of the write. Condor_chirp read uses a length param to control this.

I propose changing this such that write uses a length param like read. Such that:

/usr/libexec/condor/condor_chirp write -offset 0 -stride 0 0 /tmp/tmpfiletowrite filetowrite 10

$cat /tmp/tmpfiletowrite

abcdefghij00000000000000000000000

/usr/libexec/condor/condor_chirp write -offset 2 -stride 0 0 /tmp/tmpfiletowrite filetowrite 10

$cat /tmp/tmpfiletowrite

00abcdefghij000000000000000000000

/usr/libexec/condor/condor_chirp write -offset 2 -stride 3 4 /tmp/tmpfiletowrite filetowrite 10

$cat /tmp/tmpfiletowrite

00abc0def0ghi0j000000000000000000
remarks:
2013-Mar-21 07:46:28 by matt:
This is an RFE, it should allow the length argument to be optional for backward compatibility

2013-Mar-21 08:12:52 by jrt:
I'll rework the patch for an optional length field.

2013-Mar-21 11:36:34 by jrt:
What this appears to me to be is that chirp_write was never finished code. Chirp_read uses chirp_client_sread, but chirp_write doesn't make use of chirp_client_swrite although swrite is fully implemented (but unused) across IOProxy_handler, NTSenders,and NTReceivers.

2013-May-07 15:56:24 by eje:
TESTING

All the following tests use this input file "src.txt": 

$ cat src.txt
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz123456789A

first test is legacy functionality (no length param after source filename), so full input file is assumed: 

# script that creates a temporary destination file and writes input file src.txt into it:
$ cat chirp_gt3548_1.sh
#!/bin/sh
echo "000000000000000000000000000000000" > /tmp/dst.txt
echo "--- before ---"
cat -A /tmp/dst.txt
echo "--------------"
/home/eje/condor/release/libexec/condor_chirp write -offset 0 -stride 0 0 /tmp/dst.txt src.txt
echo "--- after ----"
cat -A /tmp/dst.txt
echo "--------------"

# job to invoke the chirp script:
$ cat gt3548_1.jsub
executable = chirp_gt3548_1.sh
universe = vanilla
userlog = gt3548_1.log
output = gt3548_1.out
error = gt3548_1.err
+WantIOProxy = true
queue 1

# run the job
$ condor_submit gt3548_1.jsub

# resulting output (notice "cat -A" displays '$' for newline)
$ cat gt3548_1.out
$ cat gt3548_1.out
--- before ---
000000000000000000000000000000000$
--------------
--- after ----
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz123456789A$
--------------

The 2nd test is a legacy test that uses "-stride 3 4", and over-runs original file length: 

# chirp with an offset and stride:
$ cat chirp_gt3548_2.sh
#!/bin/sh
echo "000000000000000000000000000000000" > /tmp/dst.txt
echo "--- before ---"
cat -A /tmp/dst.txt
echo "--------------"
/home/eje/condor/release/libexec/condor_chirp write -offset 2 -stride 3 4 /tmp/dst.txt src.txt
echo "--- after ----"
cat -A /tmp/dst.txt
echo "--------------"

# submit file
$ cat gt3548_2.jsub
executable = chirp_gt3548_2.sh
universe = vanilla
userlog = gt3548_2.log
output = gt3548_2.out
error = gt3548_2.err
+WantIOProxy = true
queue 1

# submit the job
$ condor_submit gt3548_2.jsub

# here we see overrun leaves null-chars in stride gaps (cat -A displays null chars as '^@'):
$ cat gt3548_2.out
--- before ---
000000000000000000000000000000000$
--------------
--- after ----
00abc0def0ghi0jkl0mno0pqr0stu0vwx$
yz1^@234^@567^@89A^@$
--------------

The 3rd test verifies use of new length parameter to cap the bytes of input that are written: 

# script invokes chirp write with offset, stride and a write length (10):
$ cat chirp_gt3548_3.sh
#!/bin/sh
echo "000000000000000000000000000000000" > /tmp/dst.txt
echo "--- before ---"
cat -A /tmp/dst.txt
echo "--------------"
/home/eje/condor/release/libexec/condor_chirp write -offset 2 -stride 3 4 /tmp/dst.txt src.txt 10
echo "--- after ----"
cat -A /tmp/dst.txt
echo "--------------"

# submit file
$ cat gt3548_3.jsub
executable = chirp_gt3548_3.sh
universe = vanilla
userlog = gt3548_3.log
output = gt3548_3.out
error = gt3548_3.err
+WantIOProxy = true
queue 1

# run the job
$ condor_submit gt3548_3.jsub

# verify that the write was capped at 10 characters:
$ cat gt3548_3.out
--- before ---
000000000000000000000000000000000$
--------------
--- after ----
00abc0def0ghi0j000000000000000000$
--------------
